title: Continental Express
text:
Continental Express was the operating <a href="brand">brand</a> name used by a number of independently owned <a href="regional%20airline">regional airline</a>s providing commuter airliner and regional jet feeder service under agreement with <a href="Continental%20Airlines">Continental Airlines</a>. In 2012 at the time of the merger between Continental and United Airlines, two carriers were operating using the Continental Express brand name:
Continental Express, operated by ExpressJet and Chautauqua, offered service to approximately 150 destinations in the United States, Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean, from Continental's hubs in Houston, Newark and Cleveland. ExpressJet operates as a Continental Express and United Express carrier, while Chautauqua also operated flights as <a href="Delta%20Connection">Delta Connection</a>, <a href="US%20Airways%20Express">US Airways Express</a>, <a href="Frontier%20Airlines">Frontier Airlines</a>, <a href="Midwest%20Connect">Midwest Connect</a>, <a href="Trans%20World%20Express">Trans World Express</a>, <a href="America%20West%20Express">America West Express</a>, and <a href="AmericanConnection">AmericanConnection</a>. Continental Express operated more flights to <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a> more than any other airline from its hub <a href="George%20Bush%20Intercontinental%20Airport">George Bush Intercontinental Airport</a>.
Following the merger of Continental with United, the "Continental Express" brand was discontinued and such flight services were renamed as <a href="United%20Express">United Express</a>.
History.
Continental Express/ExpressJet was at one time a wholly owned subsidiary of Continental Airlines, Inc. In this previous incarnation before its <a href="divestiture">divestiture</a> various air carriers operating as Continental Express flew turboprop aircraft such as the <a href="ATR%2042">ATR 42</a>, <a href="ATR%2072">ATR 72</a>, <a href="Beechcraft%2099">Beechcraft 99</a>, <a href="Beechcraft%201900">Beechcraft 1900</a>C/D, <a href="Convair%20580">Convair 580</a>, <a href="de%20Havilland%20Canada%20DHC-7%20Dash%207">de Havilland Canada DHC-7 Dash 7</a>, <a href="Embraer%20EMB-110%20Bandeirante">Embraer EMB-110 Bandeirante</a>, <a href="Embraer%20EMB-120%20Brasilia">Embraer EMB-120 Brasilia</a>, <a href="Fairchild%20F-27">Fairchild F-27</a>, <a href="Grumman%20Gulfstream%20I">Grumman Gulfstream I</a>, <a href="NAMC%20YS-11">NAMC YS-11</a> and <a href="Swearingen%20Metro">Swearingen Metro</a>. Continental Express/ExpressJet was formed through the merger of four separate commuter airlines that were wholly owned by Continental: <a href="Provincetown-Boston%20Airlines">Provincetown-Boston Airlines</a>, of Hyannis, MA, <a href="Bar%20Harbor%20Airlines">Bar Harbor Airlines</a>, of Bangor, ME, <a href="Britt%20Airways">Britt Airways</a>, of Terre Haute, IN, and <a href="Rocky%20Mountain%20Airways">Rocky Mountain Airways</a>, of Denver, CO. As part of the consolidation of the four commuter operations, the PBA and Rocky Mountain operating certificates were retired. The Bar Harbor certificate went to <a href="Eastern%20Airlines">Eastern Airlines</a> for its Florida Eastern Express division. The combined company that became Continental Express/ExpressJet operated under the Britt Airways operating certificate until November 2011, at which time all ExpressJet operations became part of the <a href="Atlantic%20Southeast%20Airlines">Atlantic Southeast Airlines</a> certificate. Continental Express also served Continental's Denver and Guam hubs until the early 1990s.
Continental Express was formed in 1986. Since the 1978 deregulation of the U.S. airline industry, U.S. carriers increasingly contracted flying to smaller destinations with small regional carriers; David Messing, a spokesperson with Continental Airlines Holdings in 1991, said that Continental Express was formed because, from a business standpoint, having one subsidiary airline for Continental was preferable to the previous scenario of numerous agreements with various smaller airlines.
In the 1990s the airline was headquartered in the Gateway II office complex near the grounds of <a href="George%20Bush%20Intercontinental%20Airport">Houston Intercontinental Airport</a> in Houston.
On Thursday September 4, 1997, Continental Express had its first regional jet flight. On Sunday September 7, 1997 Continental Express moved its operations at Bush Intercontinental Airport from Terminal C to Terminal B.
In the past, <a href="Trans-Colorado%20Airlines">Trans-Colorado Airlines</a> of Denver, CO, <a href="Royale%20Airlines">Royale Airlines</a> of Shreveport, LA, <a href="Air%20New%20Orleans">Air New Orleans</a> of Birmingham, AL, <a href="Mid%20Pacific%20Airlines">Mid Pacific Airlines</a> of Honolulu, HI, <a href="City%20Express">City Express</a> of Toronto, Ontario, <a href="Colgan%20Airways">Colgan Airways</a> of Manassas, VA, Southern Jersey Airways of Atlantic City New Jersey, and Gull Air of Hyannis, MA, have operated non-jet aircraft (primarily turboprops) using the Continental Express brand name. <a href="Emerald%20Air%20%28USA%29">Emerald Air</a> of Austin, TX and <a href="Royale%20Airlines">Royale Airlines</a> also operated <a href="Douglas%20DC-9-10">Douglas DC-9-10</a> jet service while <a href="Mid%20Pacific%20Air">Mid Pacific Air</a> operated <a href="Fokker%20F28">Fokker F28</a> jets and <a href="Presidential%20Airways%20%28scheduled%29">Presidential Airways</a> of Herndon, VA flew <a href="British%20Aerospace">British Aerospace</a> <a href="BAe%20146-200">BAe 146-200</a> jets on behalf of Continental.
Continental Connection and Continental Commuter.
Continental Airlines had contracted with other airlines such as <a href="Cape%20Air">Cape Air</a>, of Barnstable, MA, <a href="Colgan%20Air">Colgan Air</a>, of Manassas, VA, <a href="CommutAir">CommutAir</a>, of South Burlington, VT, <a href="GP%20Express%20Airlines">GP Express Airlines</a>, of Grand Island, NE, <a href="Gulfstream%20International">Gulfstream International</a>, of Dania Beach, FL, and <a href="SkyWest%20Airlines">SkyWest Airlines</a>, of St. George, UT to operate non-jet aircraft as <a href="Continental%20Connection">Continental Connection</a> on short-haul routes beginning in the mid 1990s. The "Continental Connection" brand name was used to identify non-jet, hosted codeshare airlines, while "Continental Express" was used as the marketing name for regional jet and some turboprop hosted codeshare operations. For example, <a href="ATR%2042">ATR 42</a>, <a href="ATR%2072">ATR 72</a> and <a href="Embraer%20EMB-120%20Brasilia">Embraer EMB-120 Brasilia</a> propjet flights were operated from the Houston hub as "Continental Express".
<a href="Envoy%20Air">American Eagle Airlines</a>, of Los Angeles, CA also operated turboprop aircraft as a code-share on behalf of Continental Airlines but was not known as Continental Connection.
<a href="Pioneer%20Airlines">Pioneer Airlines</a> of Denver, CO and <a href="Royale%20Airlines">Royale Airlines</a> of Shreveport, LA operated as Continental Commuter carriers from 1983 through 1986 and were the first code-sharing feeder carrier's on behalf of Continental Airlines. Pioneer was the feeder at Continental's Denver hub but ceased operations in mid-1986. Royale was the feeder at the Houston hub utilizing <a href="Douglas%20DC-9-10">Douglas DC-9-10</a> jets as well as <a href="Gulfstream%20I">Gulfstream I</a> propjets in addition to other commuter turboprop aircraft types and was reclassified as Continental Express by the fall of 1986.
Other subsidiary airline operations.
Two additional airlines worthy of note, which operated in connection with Continental Airlines, were <a href="New%20York%20Air">New York Air</a> and Continental West, of Los Angeles, both of which operated mainline jet aircraft. New York Air began operations in 1980 between Boston, New York/LaGuardia, and Washington/National, flying <a href="McDonnell%20Douglas%20DC-9-30">McDonnell Douglas DC-9-30</a> and <a href="MD-80">MD-80</a> jetliners, while Continental West – in a sense a predecessor of <a href="Continental%20Lite">CALite</a> – started in 1985, operating an hourly shuttle between Los Angeles and San Jose with <a href="Boeing%20737-300">Boeing 737-300</a> jets. Both airlines were started by Continental's holding company, Texas Air, in an effort to operate low cost flights, and both were folded into Continental in 1986. In addition, a third independent air carrier, <a href="Emerald%20Air%20%28USA%29">Emerald Air</a> of Austin, TX, operated the "Houston Proud Express" <a href="Douglas%20DC-9-10">Douglas DC-9-10</a> jet shuttle service on a short, crosstown route between Houston <a href="Intercontinental%20Airport">Intercontinental Airport</a> (IAH) and Houston <a href="Hobby%20Airport">Hobby Airport</a> (HOU) in the mid 1980s.
Operators and fleet.
Fleet.
<a href="ExpressJet%20Airlines">ExpressJet Holdings</a> announced on December 28, 2005, that it received notice from Continental Airlines of its intention to reduce by 69 the number of aircraft ExpressJet will operate for Continental under the companies' capacity purchase agreement. Per the agreement, ExpressJet could return the aircraft to Continental, or lease them from Continental at a higher rate and operate as a regional feeder for another airline.
As announced by Continental, the withdrawal of aircraft from the agreement was expected to begin in January 2007 and be completed during summer 2007. Simultaneously, Continental announced its intention to request proposals from other regional carriers to lease and operate the returned aircraft, beginning in January 2007. Continental announced in April 2006 that Chautauqua Airlines had been awarded a contract to operate the 69 aircraft owned by Continental.
ExpressJet later announced its intention to operate the 69 aircraft independently, at increased lease rates. As a result, <a href="Chautauqua%20Airlines">Chautauqua</a> was forced to add a new fleet type.
In July 2006, Continental Airlines announced a new contract, in which Chautauqua Airlines would provide and operate regional jets as a Continental Express carrier. As of 2009, Continental Express consisted of 214 aircraft operated by ExpressJet Airlines, and 20 aircraft operated by Chautauqua Airlines. All Express flights were then operated with regional jet aircraft; however <a href="Continental%20Connection">Continental Connection</a> flights were operated with prop aircraft configured with as few as nine seats.
By 2008 however, ExpressJet then decided to end all of its independent flying and operate all flights once again as a Continental Express carrier until November 30, 2011.

Historical turboprop fleet.
The Continental Express brand, through its various regional and commuter airline partners, operated a variety of twin turboprop aircraft over the years including the following types:
